Topic.Title: TAX CHEATER WILLARD ROMNEY WILL GO TO JAIL

Message.Msg: You're right, mrstan...given the easy access to financial experts Romney has enjoyed from his days at Cranbrook through his tenure at Bain (however long one chooses that to be), and the fact that he's been planning this campaign for 20 years, I have no doubt that Mitt isn't worried about the IRS charging him with tax evasion. He's had plenty of time and plenty of top-notch help to shape his campaign strategy, and I'm sure his returns are immensely convoluted but squeaky-clean. Whatever Mitt is hiding, the place to look for it is in the NeverNeverLand of his 'retroactive retirement' from Bain, somewhere between 1999 and 2003. The only plausible explanation for Romney's refusal to release his tax returns is that something in those returns links him to something at Bain from that period (or later) that is political kryptonite. My own theory is that he's distancing himself from involvement in the Bain-Stericycle deals, the problem being that a major segment of Stericycle's operations dealt with the disposal of aborted fetuses. Now, to clarify the issue, there is nothing inherently illegal about that business (although Stericycle WAS convicted by a Texas court in 2006 of improperly dumping human fetal remains in public landfills). The real issue is that Romney wants to avoid having to explain how and why a Good Mormon like him got involved in funding Stericycle's operation. It would also explain why Mitt eased his Pro-Life stance around that time and and shifted to tepid support of pro-choice for his gubernatorial campaign and term as governor, and then wandered back to Pro-Life after he left the governorship behind and starting chasing the Republican presidential nomination in earnest. Mitt has put a tremendous amount of effort into removing the 'Massachusetts Liberal" label he pasted on for his run for governor, and for the guy who pioneered ObamaCare in his own state, he's done a remarkable job of straddling that fence. However, straddling the Bain-Stericycle issue would require a wider stance than Larry Craig's, a position that makes it hard to run for anything other than the 'EXIT' sign. Pros and cons, pros and cons: that pretty well sums up not only Romney's political calculus, but the people who were involved in developing and implementing it as well. (IMHO of course).

Message.Title: While the Market Rallies, Here's the FED Statement it Decided to Rally On:
Message.Msg: Release Date: August 1, 2012 For immediate release Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in June suggests that economic activity decelerated somewhat over the first half of this year. Growth in employment has been slow in recent months, and the unemployment rate remains elevated. Business fixed investment has continued to advance. Household spending has been rising at a somewhat slower pace than earlier in the year. Despite some further signs of improvement, the housing sector remains depressed. Inflation has declined since earlier this year, mainly reflecting lower prices of crude oil and gasoline, and longer-term inflation expectations have remained stable. Consistent with its statutory mandate, the Committee seeks to foster maximum employment and price stability. The Committee expects economic growth to remain moderate over coming quarters and then to pick up very gradually. Consequently, the Committee anticipates that the unemployment rate will decline only slowly toward levels that it judges to be consistent with its dual mandate. Furthermore, strains in global financial markets continue to pose significant downside risks to the economic outlook. The Committee anticipates that inflation over the medium term will run at or below the rate that it judges most consistent with its dual mandate. To support a stronger economic recovery and to help ensure that inflation, over time, is at the rate most consistent with its dual mandate, the Committee expects to maintain a highly accommodative stance for monetary policy. In particular, the Committee decided today to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to 1/4 percent and currently anticipates that economic conditions--including low rates of resource utilization and a subdued outlook for inflation over the medium run--are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels for the federal funds rate at least through late 2014. The Committee also decided to continue through the end of the year its program to extend the average maturity of its holdings of securities as announced in June, and it is maintaining its existing policy of reinvesting principal payments from its holdings of agency debt and agency mortgage-backed securities in agency mortgage-backed securities. The Committee will closely monitor incoming information on economic and financial developments and will provide additional accommodation as needed to promote a stronger economic recovery and sustained improvement in labor market conditions in a context of price stability. Voting for the FOMC monetary policy action were: Ben S. Bernanke, Chairman; William C. Dudley, Vice Chairman; Elizabeth A. Duke; Dennis P. Lockhart; Sandra Pianalto; Jerome H. Powell; Sarah Bloom Raskin; Jeremy C. Stein; Daniel K. Tarullo; John C. Williams; and Janet L. Yellen. Voting against the action was Jeffrey M. Lacker, who preferred to omit the description of the time period over which economic conditions are likely to warrant an exceptionally low level of the federal funds rate.
